items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high tides.  Flooding is possible during the high tides over the next few days.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Tuesday evening, 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel river gauges as a result of heavy rain and showers over the last week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 8am today, Tuesday 04/01/22 the level at the Cae Howel gauge was 4.0m and steady. 
Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rain and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force until Thusday 6th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.   
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days, as further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force until Thusday 6th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: High water levels with sea spray are forecast as a result of high tides and increased wind speeds. First forecast high water is 20:15 on 4/1/22 with a level of 6:24 mAOD and a Force 6 North Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:30 on 5/1/22 with a level of 6.40 mAOD and a Force 5 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 5/1/22 high tide at 21:00. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow on Wednesday, 5/1/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels remain high at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past 48 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible today 04/01/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today, 04/01/2022 between 5:00PM and 6:15PM. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston, in particular around Bridlington Harbour, where Flood Warnings are in force. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blythe in Warwickshire
River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is possible today (04/01/22), particularly in the Islip area. 
The forecast this morning (04/01/22) is for showers, clearing to leave a mainly dry afternoon and evening. 
River levels in the Islip area are falling slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
This message will be updated this evening, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton between between 5:30PM and 7:45PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Hornsea North Promenade. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Areas most at risk include the north side of the dock area, properties on Harbour Road and the Floral Pavilion. Flooding is affecting the north side of the dock area, properties on Harbour Road and the Floral Pavilion between 5:00PM and 6:00PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame and Chalgrove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thame in response to recent rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (04/01/22) especially around the Thame Bridge area. 
The forecast this morning (04/01/22) is for showers, clearing to leave a mainly dry afternoon and evening. 
River levels continue to slowly rise in the Thame Bridge area. Levels in the Dorchester and Stadhampton areas remain high but steady. River levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, some of which will be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The forecast this evening (03/01/22) is mainly dry with some scattered showers overnight. Some showers are forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning (04/01/22) clearing to leave a mostly dry day tomorrow. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Welney Causeway Gauge. We expect flooding to affect the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.
This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 4th January. Lower sections of the Welney Causeway may have flood water on the road and some ponding and debris may remain. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Sutton Gault and Earith Causeways. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, however we do not expect levels to rise again significantly. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide on road closures.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels at the Bradford-on-Avon gauge have now fallen below the Flood Alert threshold and are expected to remain relatively stable for the next 48 hours.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 10:30 AM on 04/01/2022. The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the high water time. Forecasts suggests further Flood Alerts may need to be issued for high tide on Wednesday Morning. We will re-issue this alert with further details should forecasts continue to suggest that it is needed. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid flooded footpaths in the area during high tides. This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Welney Causeway in Norfolk
items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Welney Causeway river gauge as a result of rainfall last week. We expect flooding to affect The A1101 Wash Road at Welney. 
This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 4th January. Lower sections of the Welney Causeway may have flood water on the road and some ponding and debris may remain. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Some further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours, however we do not expect levels to rise again significantly. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide on road closures.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:15 on 04/01/2022 is higher than normal, with strong Northerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. The total forecast tide is 6.22 metres Chart Datum (3.17 mAOD) at Littlehampton, very similar to Tuesday morning's tide. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Tides on Wednesday (05/01/2022) are forecast to be lower with smaller waves, so no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 04/01/2022.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The Thames Barrier is expected to close today for the predicted high water at 15:30 on 04/01/22. We are not currently planning to close the Thames Barrier for the high tide overnight at 03:45 on 05/01/22. and this Flood Alert message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22 with the forecast river levels.   

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 110 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are expected to rise on the River Thames at Trowlock Island due to today's high tide at 3.15 PM (03/01/2022) where the level is expected to be between 5.0 and 5.1m. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads is expected. 
The following high tide is at 3.45 AM tomorrow (04/01/2022) where the level is expected to be between 5.1 and 5.2m. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads is also expected for this tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/01/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
Coast from Gretna to Silloth
Coast from Silloth to St Bees
Coast at North Morecambe Bay
Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is due in the Severn Estuary until Wednesday evening the 5/1/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present. The A417 at Maisemore could be closed due to flooding. Low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.5m at 10:15 on 04/01/22, Gloucester 3.2m to 3.5m at 10:00 on 04/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
This message will be updated by 11:00am on 4/1/2022 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at Barrow in Furness
Mersey Estuary at Warrington
Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Tide levels tomorrow will be higher than usual as a result of a combination of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest at 07:00 tomorrow morning and 19:15 tomorrow evening, 04/01/22. Flooding is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours  either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront.
 
The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.63mAODN.The forecast surge height is 0.89m.The forecast tide level is 4.52mAOD.The forecast wind direction is North-Westerly. The forecast wind strength is Force 5. 

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message: Strong winds and high tides are forecast to cause wave overtopping and spray at Berwick Between the Bridges on the Tweed Estuary. Tides will be at their highest between 03:00 and 05:30, tomorrow morning, 04/01/2022. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply up to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Property flooding is not expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 7:45 AM on 04/01/2022. The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the high water time. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.. Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves and a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Monday evening and Tuesday morning. This will lead to high tidal levels along The South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 18:30 on Monday 3rd January 2022 and 07:00 on Tuesday 4th January 2022, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. If conditions continue to deteriorate, the A1077 flood gate across the A1077 may be closed. A further message will be issued if this becomes apparent, together with further Flood Warnings. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, have staff checking defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves and a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England on Tuesday morning. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the East Coast, between Humberston to Gibraltar Point. The time and date of the forecast high water is 07:00 on Tuesday 4th January 2022 and 19:15 on Tuesday 4th January 2022, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:30am and 8:30am Tuesday 4 January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.73 mAODN at 7:30am, Tuesday 4 January, which is 0.84m above tide tables, wind Force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The tide on Tuesday 4th January at 7:15pm is forecast to result in increased flood risk, we will update the situation before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

items.description: South Devon Estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday morning. High water at Plymouth is at 6:30am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
High spring tides are forecast to cause minor flooding in exposed coastal locations including at the quayside at Kingsbridge, footpaths in Totnes and minor roads throughout the estuaries.  
Expect tides to be around 260mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
Strong force 7 northerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.3m are forecast along the coast. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at 6:30am is 2.83 mAOD, this is 0.26 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:30am and 8:30am Tuesday 4 January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.73 mAODN at 7:30am, Tuesday 4 January, which is 0.84m above tide tables, wind Force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The tide on Tuesday 4 January at 7:15pm is forecast to result in increased flood risk, we will update the situation before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9:30am and 11:30am, on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft, as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.89 mAODN at 10:30am, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.8m above tide tables, wind Force 4, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). The tides this evening and tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January, are also forecast to reach flood alert. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 2:45pm on Tuesday 4th January. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.04 mAODN at 12:45pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.76m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 04/01/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Northerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.25 m. The total forecast tide is 5.21 metres Chart Datum (2.48 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Any impacts will be very minor, and confined to roads, footpaths and car parks at the immediate sea front. For 30 minutes either side of high tide, water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. Water may flow into the bottom third of Langstone High Street, but if this occurs, flood depths in the road will be shallow. After this tide‚ levels are reducing and no further impacts are expected. In Emsworth, to help reduce flood risk, we have already lowered the level of the Mill Pond. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, if you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 17:00 on 04/01/2022.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: A large tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown tomorrow lunchtime, Tuesday 04/01/22, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 11:30 and 12:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 04/01/22, with high tide at 11:45. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 12:45 on 05/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes. Please remain aware of your local situation. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.07m AOD and the total water level will be 3.76m AOD.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: A large tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore from St Margaret’s at Cliffe to Sandgate, Dover and Folkestone tomorrow lunchtime, Tuesday 04/01/22, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 11:30 and 12:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 04/01/22, with high tide at 11:45. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 12:45 on 05/01/22. items.description: Dorset coast at Poole Harbour

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 10:00 AM on 04/01/2022. The Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the time of high water.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle. Hamworthy Recreation Park may start to experience minor flooding.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Take extra care and avoid flooded areas.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible between 6:30PM and 8:00PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Hessle Haven, and Hessle Foreshore and North Ferriby. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. The new flood gates around Hessle foreshore have been closed and will remain closed for the next few days until the high tidal levels pass. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes

items.description: North Sea at Whitby Harbour
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Areas most at risk include low spots in the Whitby harbour area including Abrahams Quay, Pier Road, New Quay Road, Church Street, Campion Dock and Bagdale Road. Flooding is expected between 4:30PM and 5:00PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary from Kilnsea to Skeffling and Weeton
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Areas most at risk include properties along the Humber in the Kilnsea, Skeffling and Weeton areas. Flooding is expected between 5:45PM and 7:00PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Areas most at risk include Hessle area around Hessle Haven. Flooding is affecting Hessle area around Hessle Haven between 7:00PM and 7:45PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. The new flood gates at Hessle foreshore have been closed, and will remain closed for the next few days, until levels reduce. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Waves and spray combined with high tidal levels are forecast to overtop coastal frontages in Hornsea and could affect North Promenade, Marine Drive, South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck between 5:00PM and 7:30PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Coastal floodgates in Hornsea have been closed. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Dartford to Allhallows
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide expected today, Tuesday the 4th of January, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 11:15 to 15:15 today, with high tide expected at 13:15. Areas of concern include Royal Pier Road in Gravesend and low lying land nearest the sea.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tide at 14:15 tomorrow, the 05/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond if required.
 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. For those that use it, the astronomical water level for the 13:15 tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.01 mAOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.85 mAOD. The wind will be a force 5 Northerly wind. This message will be updated this afternoon or as the situation changes.

items.description: Thorney Island to Bracklesham
items.message: Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 04/01/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Northerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.36 m. The total forecast tide is 5.31 metres Chart Datum (2.57 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Around Chichester harbour, some gardens or land at shore side properties could also be affected. After this tide‚ peak water levels are forecast to fall by at least 15cm and only minimal impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 04/01/2022

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 14:15 on 04/01/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Beaulieu estuary
items.message: Tuesday morning's tide at 11:42 on 04/01/2022 and 13:36 on 04/01/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Northerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.35 m. The total forecast tide is 4.18 metres Chart Datum (2.18 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 30 minutes either side of the first high water, the tide may flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Some shallow flooding may affect Palace Lane, which will make road access to the village temporarily more difficult. After this tide‚ levels are reducing and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will remove this message by 17:00 on 04/01/2022.

items.description: Isolated riverside properties on the tidal River Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is possible between 10:45am and 2:45pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Martlesham Bridge, including those on Bealings Road, School Lane and Sandy Lane. Also, riverside areas around Waldringfield and Methersgate Quay. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.01 mAODN at 12:45pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.82m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.
